title: Saul Anointed King
shortSummary: In 1 Samuel 10, the prophet Samuel anoints Saul as the first king of Israel, marking a pivotal moment in Israel’s history. Saul receives divine confirmation through prophetic signs and the Spirit of the Lord, and is publicly chosen by lot before the people. Despite some initial rejection, Saul is established as God’s appointed leader.
timeline: c. 1050 BC - The Establishment of the Monarchy in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Samuel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet and judge who anoints Saul as king and leads Israel through this transitional period.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: Son of Kish from the tribe of Benjamin, chosen and anointed by God through Samuel to be Israel’s first king.

keyCharacters.name: Saul’s Uncle
keyCharacters.description: A relative who inquires about Saul’s journey and Samuel’s message, providing insight into Saul’s initial humility.

definitions.definition: To pour oil on someone’s head as a sign of being chosen and set apart by God for a special role or office.
To speak forth God’s message under the influence of the Holy Spirit, often including inspired speech or song.
The empowering presence of God that enables individuals to fulfill His purposes, such as prophecy or leadership.
A sacrificial offering wholly consumed by fire, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.

outline.heading: Samuel Anoints Saul and Gives Signs
outline.description: Samuel anoints Saul with oil, symbolizing God’s selection of him as king, and foretells specific signs Saul will encounter confirming his divine appointment. Saul receives a new heart and the Spirit of the Lord comes upon him, empowering him for his new role.

outline.heading: Saul Prophesies Among the Prophets
outline.description: Saul meets a group of prophets and begins to prophesy, demonstrating the transformative power of the Spirit. This surprises those who knew him, leading to the proverb about Saul among the prophets.

outline.heading: Saul’s Family and the Search for Him
outline.description: Saul’s uncle questions him about his journey and Samuel’s message, but Saul withholds the full revelation about the kingdom, showing his humility and unawareness of the full implications.

outline.heading: The Public Selection of Saul as King
outline.description: Samuel gathers Israel at Mizpeh and recounts God’s faithfulness despite Israel’s rejection of Him. By casting lots, Saul is chosen from the tribe of Benjamin and publicly acclaimed as king, confirmed by his impressive stature.

outline.heading: Samuel’s Instructions and Saul’s Reception
outline.description: Samuel explains the duties of the monarchy and records them before the Lord. Saul returns home with supporters, but some reject him, doubting his ability to save Israel, highlighting the challenges ahead.

application: Trust God’s sovereign choice and timing, even when His plans surprise or challenge our expectations.
Be open to the transforming work of the Holy Spirit, which can change our hearts and empower us for God’s purposes.
Respond to God’s calling with humility, even when the full scope of His plan is not yet clear.
Support and pray for God’s appointed leaders, recognizing that opposition and criticism may come.

keyVerses.text: Then Samuel took a vial of oil, and poured it upon his head, and kissed him, and said, Is it not because the LORD hath anointed thee to be captain over his inheritance?
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the divine appointment of Saul as king through the symbolic act of anointing by Samuel.

keyVerses.text: And the Spirit of the LORD will come upon thee, and thou shalt prophesy with them, and shalt be turned into another man.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the transformative power of the Holy Spirit in preparing Saul for his leadership role.

keyVerses.text: And Samuel said to all the people, See ye him whom the LORD hath chosen, that there is none like him among all the people? And all the people shouted, and said, God save the king.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the public recognition and acceptance of Saul as God’s chosen king.
